name: C6
comment: The classic lap steel tuning. For C6 strings.

name: C6-8
comment: C6 for 8 strings

name: C6/A7
comment: C6/A7 for regular guitar strings

name: Leavitt tuning
comment: All intervals and a lot of jazz voicings

name: Reverse Leavitt
comment: What if we turn Leavitt around

name: Leavitt tuning (extra bass)
comment: All intervals and a lot of jazz voicings

name: Hexatonic
comment: A lot of chords, good for jazz. For C6 strings.

name: Hexatonic+
comment: One more minor third on top for straight dom7 chords

name: Hexatonic++
comment: Hexatonic-Leavitt hybrid

name: Almost hexatonic
comment: Power chords

name: B11
comment: Sand by Jerry Byrd

name: Diatonic
comment: By Jerry Byrd

name: G13
comment: Chord-based

name: Another all-intervals mashup
comment: Leavitt tuning contains all intervals except the m2 and the octave. This one does too and has a bit more of the simpler chords. C6 strings, optionally with a thicker fifth string

name: Six scraps
comment: One semitone less range than Leavitt and no M6 interval under a straight bar. However roots, dominants and powerchords are plenty. For C6 strings.

name: Open G
comment: Open G. For regular guitar strings

name: Open E
comment: Same intervals as open G. For regular guitar strings

name: Open D
comment: Open D. For regular guitar strings

name: Spanish
comment: Standard

name: DADGAD
comment: Dsus2

name: All fourths (P4)
comment: What if guitar was regularly tuned

name: All fifths
comment: Theoretical, not seen on steels

name: All major thirds (M3)
comment: What if guitar was regularly tuned in thirds

name: Alternating thirds
comment: Alternate between minor and major thirds

name: Alkire E-Harp
comment: For 10 strings with gauges 36 32, 30, 28, 26, 24, 22, 20, 18, 16
